Slovenia, Carniola. Violani and Zava (1995) restricted the type locality of G. glis to Southern Carniola, Slovenia, based on a letter written by Scopoli describing the Fat Dormouse to Linnaeus, who was unacquainted with the animal. Scopoli gave the following locality information, "Habitat in Carniola, in primis inferiore", which Violani and Zava (1995) translated to mean "Southern Carniola". An alternate translation of "Habitat in Carniola, in primis inferiore." is "dwells in Carniola, principally Southern." Krystufek is of the opinion that Scopoli likely became acquainted with the Fat Dormouse in the vicinity of Idrija, central Slovenia, where Scopoli worked as a physician, and where Fat Dormice are still common (B. Krytufek, pers. comm.). Unless additional locality information is uncovered regarding the Scopoli specimen, it seems more accurate to list the type locality as simply Carniola.

Papua New Guinea (= "British New Guinea"), Central Province, Astrolabe Range behind Port Moresby. The specimen was collected by Dr. Lamberto Loria between 1890 and 1893 and Tate (1951:223) claimed that "Loria collected in the Astrolabe Range behind Port Moresby," but Laurie and Hill, 1954:132 noted that no exact locality was published. Thomas (1897a:4), however wrote that Lorias localities "are mostly between the Owen Stanley Range and the sea, in or near the watershed of the Kemp Welch river," an area that would include the Astrolabe Range and adjacent Sogeri Plateau.

Specified as unknown in the original description. Cabrera (1958) restricted the type locality to Lagoa Sanata, Minas Gerais, Brazil, but Goodwin (1959b) disagreed. Based on measurements and cranial morphology, Goodwin (1959b) concluded that the holotype was probably from Antigua, Lesser Antilles. Handley and Gardner (1990) subsequently confirmed the identity of the holotype and confirmed restriction of the type locality to Antigua.

"L'ile Decrs" [Australia, South Australia, Kangaroo Isl].
"Strait of Magellan".

"Falkland Islands and Cape Horn." Locality in error; fixed by Clark (1873b) as "Auckland Islands. . . between 800 and 900 miles [1287 and 1448 km] S. of Tasmania, in lat. 5048'S., long. 16642'E." [New Zealand].
"les rochers dans le voisinage de la baie San-Francisco sont ordinairement couverts de lion marins." [USA, California, San Francisco Bay].
Japan.
"Floreana, (Sancta Maria), Galapagos Islands."
"intra Zonam arcticam Europae, Asiae, Americae".
"Habitat in Groenlandia australiori et Newfoundland". [S Greenland and Newfoundland].
"ad Scotiam atque Groelandiam australiorem, vulgaris circa Islandiam" [North Atlantic, S Greenland].
Listed by Scheffer (1958) as "Greenland".
"Wohnt um die Kurilischen Inseln" [Russia, Kurile Isls].
"des environs des les Falckland ou Malouines" [Falkland Isls (UK)].
"sur les ctes des Orcades australes, situes sour 60 degrs 37 minutes de lat" [South Orkney Isl (Br. Antarct. Trust Terr.)].

"captur sur les glaces du Pole Sud, entre les les Sandwich et les les Powels,  150 lieues de distance de chacune de ces les." [Scotia Sea (midway between South Orkney and South Sandwich Isls) (Br. Antarct. Trust Terr.)].

"California" restricted by Poole and Schantz (1942) to "St. Bartholomews Bay, lower California, Mexico." Clarified by Scheffer (1958) as "Baha Trtola (= Baha San Bartolom) 2739'N, 11451'W, Baja California, Mexico".
"ad polum Antarcticum" restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Juan Fernandez", further restricted by Hamilton (1940) as "Isla Mas a Tierra" [Chile].
"Dalmation Sea at Ossero." [Serbia and Montenegro] King (1956).
"Laysan ist eine kleine Koralleinsel, nordwestlich der Sandwich-Inseln" [USA, Laysan Isl, 2550'N, 17150'W].
"Jamaica" restricted by King (1956) to "Pedro Cays, 80 km. south of Jamaica".
"Antarctic ocean", restricted by Barrett-Hamilton (1902) to "pack ice, north of Ross Sea 68S, 176E".
"in Groenlandia et Newfoundland."
"quam quod observetur tantum ad orientale littus Camtschatcae" [Eastern coast of Kamchatka, Russia (Shaughnessy and Fay, 1977)].
"in mari Europo" restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Mari Bothnico et Baltico", however, presently it does not occur in the Gulf of Bothnia (Bobrinski et al., 1944).
"in mari, praesertim septentrionali, etiam Pacifico et Caspico" [Caspian Sea].
"Man fngt ihn auf den Ksten von Grnland und Labrader".
"Baikal et Orom" [Lake Baikal and Lake Oron (=Ozero Oron), Russia].
"Capischer otter. . Afrika" [South Africa, (former) Cape Province].
"Batavia" [Indonesia, Java, Jakarta].

"Asia et America septentrionali," restricted by Thomas (1911a), to"Kamtchatka", then by Heptner et al. (1967:884) to "Commander Isls" [Russia]. Roest (1973) listed the type locality as "the east central coast of Kamchatka, opposite the Commander Islands" [Russia].
"Kafferlandes am stlichen Abhange der Bambusberge."

"Der Fischotter ...Europa berall gemein... Einwohner des nordlichen Theils von Asien, bis nach Kamatschatka hinaus, und ...Persian hinunter, und von Nordamerika." Miller (1912b:113) listed the type locality as "Eastern Canada".
"Chili" [Chile].
"Brasilien."
"south of Lake Nahuel Huapi, Patagonia" [Argentina].
"Europ aquis dulcibus, fluviis, flagnis, piscinis," subsequently restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Upsala" [Sweden].
"Nenokubi Seaside, Shimoda, Nakamura City, Kchi Prefecture."
"Sumatra (Raffles); Malacca (B.M.)," restricted by Pocock (1941a) to "Sumatra."
"Sumatra" [Indonesia].
"in fluviis americae meridionalis"; Cabrera (1957:274) restricted to "ri So Francisco, en la orilla correspondiente al estado de Alagoas", Brazil.
"dans les montagnes qui sparent le Boutan de l'Indoustan."
"Brasilia," restricted by Lnnberg (1913) to "Pernambuco."

"Chili" restricted by Thomas (1912e) to "S. Chili (Temuco)"; Cabrera (1957) restricted the locality to "alrededores de Santiago" [Chile]. Honacki et al. (1982) listed the type locality for G. c. furax.
"Surinam".
"alpibus Lapponi, Ruffiae, Sibiriae, sylvis vastissimis", restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Lapland".
"Libyae" [Libya].
"South America". This is clearly in error and Hollister (1918) fixed the type locality as "Cape of Good Hope". [South Africa].
Listed in Cabrera (1957) as "cercanas del ro Negro." [Argentina].
"North America".
Not given; fixed by Pocock (1941a) as "Nepal".
"Europa inque Persia", listed by Miller (1912a) as "Germany."
"Madras" [India].
"sylvis antiquis", restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Upsala" [Sweden].
"Japan."
"in America boreali, vulgaris victitans quadrupedibus minoribus." Listed by Miller and Rehm (1901) as "Eastern Canada."

"asia septentrionali," restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "N. Asia." Restricted by Ognev (1931:562) to "Tobol'skaya gub. v ee severnoi chasti" ["northern part of Tobol'sk Province" (1962 translation)] [Russia].
"Europa inter rimas rupium et lapidum," restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Upsala" [Sweden].
"Vorgebirge der guten Hofnung" [South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape of Good Hope].
"Mount Kina Balu, N. Borneo, about 4000 ft. [1219 m]"
"China," restricted by Allen (1929) to "Canton, Kwangtung Province, South China."

"limited...to...south of Mountain Prahu, between the two prinicpal cones of the central part of Java, the Mountain Sumbing, and...Teggal, ...Baggulen and Banyumas...to Gowong in the east." [Indonesia, Java].
"environs de Rangoun" [Burma].
"Africa", type locality is in error, fixed by Cabrera (1957) as "arrabales de Belem, la antigua Par." [Brazil]
"qui alpes altaicas adibunt" [Altai Mtns].
"Europa and Asia frigidiore; hyeme praefertim in alpinis regionibus nivea".

"trouv...entre Orembourg et Bukkara," restricted by Stroganov (1962:338) to "bassein srednego techeniya r. Ileka, v raione vpadenya ...r. Bol'shoi Khobdy" [Russia, Orenburg Obl., south of Orenburg, mouth of Bol'shaya Khobda River, a tributary of Ilek River].
"Santa Marta, elevation 2,700 m, near San Agustin, Huila, Colombia".
"der Nhe von Mexico"[placed in Ciudad Mexico, Mexico].
"Kachar region" [Nepal].
"Finlandiae aquolis", restricted by Matschie (1912) to "Sdwest-Finnland."
"Tjibodas, West Java, 5500' [1676 m]"; identified by Van Bree and Boeadi (1978) as "644'S 10700'E".
"lower waters of the Platte River", restricted by Hayden (1863:138) to "Fort Laramie" [Wyoming, USA].
"Westrobothnia" [Sweden].
"L'le de Java". Locality is in error, fixed by Robinson and Kloss (1919b) as "West Sumatra" [Indonesia].
"inter Europae rupes et lapidum acervos", restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Scania, S. Sweden."

"Sibiriae montanis, sylvis densissimis", restricted by Pocock (1941a) to "Vorposten Tigerazkoi, near Usstkomengorsk, W. Altai," based on Pallas (1773:570) [U.S.S.R., E. Kazakhstan, vic. of Ust-Kamenogorsk, Tigeretskoie (Honacki et al., 1982)].
Not given. Gray (1853) based the type description on a manuscript given to him by Hodgson. Horsfield (1855) later fixed the type locality as "the Sikim Hills of Tarai." [India, Sikkim].
"In domibus aegyptiacis Cahirae et Alexandriae murium vulgaris socius"
"Brooklin, Handcock County, Maine." [Brooklin archaeological site on Black Isl, Maine].
"Man findet das Vison in Canada un Pensilvanien". Larivire (1999c) listed type locality as "Eastern Canada".
"it was without any habitat". Fixed by Coetzee (1977b) as "Cape Colony".
"Er wohnt in Labrador und um die Hudsonsbay," restricted by Long (1972a), to "Carman, Manitoba." [Canada].
"habitat in campis apricis desertis Tanaicensibus" [U.S.S.R., Rostov Obl., steppes at lower Don River (Honacki et al., 1982)].
"Chili," restricted by Cabrera (1957) to "alrededores de Valparaso." [Chile].
"Magellan Straits." [Chile].
"oberen Lauf des Rio Alvarado" [Mexico, Veracruz, Rio Alvarado]
"Mexico"; Cabrera (1958) listed the type locality as "Minas de Montuosa, cerca de Pamplona, departamento del norte de Santander, Colombia".
"Gebirgs-Gegenden nordwestlich von der Stadt Mexico." [Mexico, mountains NW of Mexico City].
"Amerika".
"l'le de Java." [Indonesia, Java].
"l'ile Palaouan" [Philippine Isls, Palawan].
"America septentrionali" restricted by Thomas (1911a), to "South Carolina." [USA].
"Rosario, Sinaloa, W. Mexico."
"Sarayacu, on the Bobonasa river, Upper Pastasa river" [Ecuador].
"Bastrica woods, Essequibo River, British Guiana".
"Costa Rica" restricted by Allen (1908) to "Talamanca".
"Estrella de Cartago, Costa Rica. This locality is six to eight miles [10 to 13 km] south of Cartago near the source of the Rio Estrella, at an altitude of about 4, 500 feet [1372 m]."
"Between Rio Chiriqui Viejo and Rio Colorado, on a hill known locally as Cerro Pando, elevation 4800 feet [1463 m], about ten miles [16 km] from El Volcan, Province de Chiriqui, R. de Panama."
"Mexico" [near city of Mexico].
"Cet animal habite les greniers dans la rgion chaude du Mexique." Hall and Kelson (1959) listed "Mexico, Veracruz, Mirador."
"America", restricted by Allen (1879) to "Veracruz, Mexico"; Hershkovitz (1951) further restricted it to "Achotal, Isthmus of Techuantpec, Vera Cruz."
"America"; listed by Cabrera (1957) as "Pernambuco" [Brazil].
"Santa F de Bogota" [Colombia], subsequently restricted by Cabrera (1957:249) to "Bogot, lo que debe interpretarse como las montaas prximas a esta capital"

"Er ist, der Sage nach, auf den Gebirgen in Jamaica einheimisch"; restricted by Thomas (1902b) to "Surinam". Ford and Hoffmann (1988) and Husson (1978) discussed the confusion over the name and type locality.
"se trouve  Cayenne" [French Guiana, Cayenne].
"Americ maritimis," restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Pennsylvania" [USA].
"Cozumel Island, Yucatan" [Mexico].
"Indes orientales".
"Habitat in oriente" (= Middle East?).
"The flat parts near the Cape", now identified as South Africa, Northern Cape Prov., Kuruman Dist., Little Klibbolikhonni Fontein (Grubb, 1999:16).
"Habitat in Europa" (= Sweden?); based on domestic horses.
Described as "region de l'Afrique orientale qu'on appelle le pays des Gallas", i.e. Ethiopia, Gallaland, Shoa Prov. (Rzasnicki, 1951), restricted to Awash Valley (Yalden et al., 1986).
"ad Lacum Tarei Dauuriae", i.e. Russia, Transbaikalia, S Chitinsk. Obl., Tarei-Nor, 50N, 115E.
"Ladak" (India, Kashmir).
"Caffrorum regione"; locality of paralectotype now identified as South Africa, Northern Cape Prov., Colesburg Dist., Seekoei River (Grubb, 1999).
"Habitat in India, Africa", since restricted to South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Ceres Dist., Perdekop.
"Isthmus of Panama", restricted to Panama, Canal Zone by Hershkovitz (1954).
"la presqu'ile de Malacca", i.e. Malaysia, Malay Peninsula.
"une journe de cette ville [Bogota], dans le Paramo de Suma-Paz," i.e., Colombia, Cundinamarca, Pramo de Sumapaz.
"Habitat in Brasilia", i.e., Brazil, Pernambuco.
"L'interior de l'Afrique Mridionale vers le vingt-sixime degr de latitude"; since identified as South Africa, North West Prov., Chue Spring (= Heuningvlei), about 2615'S, 2310'E. See Grubb (1999).
"Sumatra", now known to be Indonesia, Sumatra, Bencoolen (= Bintuhan) Dist., Fort Marlborough (Groves, 1967c).
"Habitat in India", now identified as South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape of Good Hope.
"Sumatra" (Indonesia), later corrected to "Java" (Indonesia).
"Habitat in Africa, India", now identified as India, Assam, Terai.
"Habitat in Borneo Indiae orientalis"; identified as "Island of Boero" by Thomas (1911a) (Indonesia, Buru Isl).
Kenya, "Nandi Forest, near the Victoria Nyanza, at an altitude of 7000 feet"; Nandi Forest, near Kaimosi [2134 m] (Allen and Lawrence, 1936).
"Promontoria Bona Spei advectus"; between Kaffraria and Great Namaqualand (South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov.), two hundred leagues from the Cape of Good Hope according to Vosmaer (1766).
"Habitat in Africa a capite viridi ad caput bonae spei"; restricted to Senegal, "Cape Verd [Verde]" (Lydekker, 1915:373).
"Madagascar" (no precise locality) here selected.
"Habitat in Africa" (West Africa); based on animals exported to Brazil (Simoons, 1953).
Philippines, "Palauan" (Palawan Isl).

Indonesia, "Borneo", Kalimantan; "Borno, [near] Banjermassing [Banjarmasin]" (Jentink, 1892:192); "the neighborhood of the village Poeloe-Lampej [Pululampei], not off [i.e. not far from?] the bank of the Moloekko-river [Molukko River], South-eastern Borneo" (Jentink, 1905:161).
Viet Nam, Cochin China, "sur les bords du Donna" (= Dong Nai River); the type is labelled "Bienhoa" (Viet Nam).
Philippines, "l'ile de Cebu".
Indonesia, "Celebes"; the type is from "Clbes, Mnado" (Sulawesi, Manado) according to Jentink (1892:193).
Philippines, Luzon Isl.
"Habitat, Saul forest" but no locality given; N India, "Sikhim Tarai [Sikkim Terai]  The moist forest-tract at the base of the eastern Himalaya" (Lydekker, 1915:343).
"Habitat in Europa australiore"; shown to be Germany, from where wild boar had been introduced to Sweden, Oeland (Thomas, 1911a:140).
Indonesia, "Java"; "Java, Palang" (Jentink, 1892:191).
Argentina, "Llajta-Maiica, tres leguas al noreste de Melero provincia de Santiago del Estero. poca moderna (precolombiana)"..

"Habitat in Mexici, Panamae, Brasiliae montibus, sylvis". Mexico selected by Thomas (1911a:140); however, Linnaeus's name Sus tajacu is based on the tajacu of Marcgraf, from Brazil, Pernambuco (Cabrera, 1961:319; Hershkovitz, 1963, 1987b) and this restriction of the type locality is adopted here.
No locality cited; identified as French Guiana, Cayenne (Hershkovitz, 1963).
Liberia, "the river St. Pauls, a stream that rises in the mountains of Guinea, and passing through the Dey country and Liberia, empties into the Atlantic to the north of Cape Messurado".
"Habitat in Nilo & Bambolo Africae et ad ostia fluviorum Asiae"; restricted to River Nile (Thomas, 1911a:155) in Egypt (G. M. Allen, 1939:457).
"Habitat in Africa"; identified as "Bactria" (Uzbekistan, Bokhara) by Thomas (1911a:150); based on domesticated stock.
"Habitat in America meridionali", identified as "Peru", Andes, by Thomas (1911a:150); based on domesticated stock.
Chile, "abondano nella parte della Cordigliera spettante alle Provincie de Coquimbo, e di Copiap" (cordilleras of Coquimbo and Copiapo).
"Sierra Leone".
"in Ceylona" (Sri Lanka).
Indonesia, W Java, Udjung Kulon Peninsula, "Nieu Bay" (Meeuwenbaai or Muara Tjikuja), Jankolan (Djungkulan) kampong; identified by Van Bemmel (1949b) and Hoogerwerf (1970:353).
Indonesia, "Sumatra"; restricted to the southern part of Sumatra by Sody (1931:355).
"Me Song forest, Pre, North Siam" (N Thailand, Song forest, Muang Pre, Meh Lem, 1825'N, 10023'E, according to Meijaard and Groves, 2004).
China, "Changling region (3110'42''N, 11553'48''E, altitude 500 m), Jinzhai county, Anhui province".
"Mountain dfil [sic] Ho-tzi-how, environs of town Lun-ngan-fu, Sze-chuan, China" (China, Sichuan, near Lungan, Ho-tsi-how Pass).

"Cis and Trans Hemelayan regions"; "lofty mountains of the interior of Tibet, especially towards the Chinese frontier, where the first and loveliest, or Chrysogaster, is almost exclusively found I have specimens of all three species [chrysogaster, leucogaster, saturatus] from Lassa and Digurchee" (Hodgson, 1842, J. Asiatic Soc. Bengal, 6:285). (China, Tibetan Plateau).
India or Pakistan, "Kashmir (no precise locality)".
China, "Bapo, Gongshan-Xian, Yunnan. Altitude 3,500 m".

"Cis and Trans Hemelayan regions"; "lofty mountains of the interior of Tibet ... On the Tibetan slopes of the Himanchal, Saturatus chiefly resides ...I have specimens of all three species [chrysogaster, leucogaster, saturatus] from Lassa and Digurchee, whilst my garden is seldom deprived of the ornament of several live families of the Saturatus of the Kachar [Alpine life-zone]" (Hodgson, 1842, J. Asiatic Soc. Bengal, 6:285) (Nepal, Himalayas).
"Habitat in Tataria versus Chinam"; restricted to Russia, SW Siberia, Altai Mtns by Heptner et al. (1961).
"Habitat in boroealibus Europae, Asiaeque Populetis"; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:151).
"Country north of Whitestown". USA, New York, probably in the western Adirondack region.
No locality given; based on the gouazoupoukou of Azara; restricted to Paraguay, Lake Ypo, south of Asuncion (Cabrera, 1961:329).
"Habitat in Europa, Asia"; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:151).

"In campestribus et montanis fruticosis ultra Volgam"; identified as Russia, former Samar district or province (Orenburgskaia Obl.), source of River Sok (a left tributary of the Volga), Bugulma-Belebei uplands (Heptner et al. 1961; Rossolimo in litt.).
"du versant oriental des Cordillieres"; Bolivian Andes, near La Paz, at about 3,500 m (Cabrera, 1961:333).
Chile, "delle Andi [Andes]"; restricted to Colchagua Prov. (Cabrera, 1961:334).
"Habitat in Guiania et Brazilia" and also cited from Surinam; restricted to French Guiana, Cayenne (Cabrera, 1961:335).

"Esta espcie, aparentemente, se distribui nos poucos fragmentos de Mata Atlntica existentes no sudeste do Estado de So Paulo e nordeste do Estado do Paran"; type from Brazil, So Paulo, Capo Benito (J. M. Barbanti Duarte, in litt.).
"Cocopunco, a site on the eastern slope of the Cordillera Real on the road to Mapiri, La Paz, Bolivia; altitude, about 3200 meters".
"Paraqu." (Paraguay); restricted to Asuncion region (Cabrera, 1961:339).
Brazil, "Ro Grande do Sul".
Mexico, "Tunkas, Yucatan".
Ecuador, "la valle de Lloa, sur le versant occidental de la Cordillire du Pichincha" (Pichincha, Pichincha Mtns, Lloa valley).
No locality cited but reference made to "Hernand. hist. nat. mexic. p. 325". Restricted by Hershkovitz (1951) to Mexico, Veracruz, Mirador.
USA, South Dakota, mouth of Big Sioux River (Bailey, 1926:41).
"Bewohnt in grossen Heerden Carolina v), Virginien, Louisiana w), und geht vielleicht bis Panama x) hinunter"; restricted by Hershkovitz (1948c:43) to USA, Virginia.
"Habitat in America australis"; identified as Brazil, Pernambuco (Thomas, 1911a:151).
Ecuador, Napo-Pastaza Prov., "Paramo of Papallacta  east of Quito, only just south of the Equator  about 11,000 feet [3353 m] above the sea".
Chile, "Cordigliera  delle Province Australi"; restricted to "los bosques del lago Todos los Santos, en la provincia de Chilo" (Cabrera, 1961:343).
"Habitat in Alpibus Europae et Asiae maxime septentrionalibus"; identified as Sweden, Alpine Lapland by Thomas (1911a:151); based on domesticated stock.
"Habitat ad ripas Gangis; in Iana, Ceylona"; restricted to India, Bihar, banks of the Ganges River (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott, 1951:360).
Philippines, "l'ile Calamian et l'isle de la Paragua [= Palawan Isl.]"; restricted to Calamian Isls, Culion Isl (Lydekker, 1915:59).
Indonesia, "les les Bavian" (= Bawean Isl).
No locality given, based on captive in Bengal; "Indo-Gangetic Plain of India" (Lydekker, 1915:56); here restricted to India, West Bengal.
"Habitat in Europa, Asia"; identified as S Sweden by Thomas (1911a:151).
"Les les du domaine du Japon"; restricted to Japan, Kyushu, Nagasaki (Groves and Smeenk, 1978).
"Habitat in Europa"; identified as "Habitat in vivariis Regis & Magnatum" by Thomas (1911a:151), in Sweden to which it had been introduced.
China, Sichuan, "la principaut de Moupin" (= Baoxing).
China, "dans le parc imprial situ  quelque distance de Pkin [Beijing]".
Malaysia, Borneo, "near forest camp 1, Cocoa Research Station, Tawau, Saba [= Sabah], 800 ft. [244 m]"
"Vicinity of Ningpo, China" (= China, Zhejiang, near Ningpo).
Burma, "Thagat Juva, a S. E. del Monte Mooleyit [= Mt. Mulaiyit], Tenasserim".
China, "Mijiao (2735' N., 9847' E.), Puladi, Gongshan county, East slope of the northern sector of Gaoligong Mountain, north-western Yunnan".
Indonesia, "Java".
"China"; "Near Canton, Kwantung [Guangdong], Southern China" (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott, 1951:357).
"Muong Yo, Laos. Altitude 2,300 feet [701 m]."

Vietnam, "in the west of Quang Nam province"; "collected from four houses in three locations in Hien District, West Quang Nam Province, Vietnam  The three locations are: Hien, the District capital, A Tin village, and A Plo village (1556'59''N, 10734'18''E)" (Giao et al., 1998). The type locality is one of these three places.
"Vu Quang Nature Reserve in Ha tinh province of Vietnam".
China, Gansu, 3 km above mouth of Kokusu River, Humboldt Mtns, Nan Shan (Flerov, 1960).
"des Indes"; restricted to N India, Uttar Pradesh, Kumaun by Groves (1982b:624).
India, Assam, "the valley of Munipore" (Manipur).
"probably inhabiting Siam [Thailand]"; occurrence in central plains of Thailand since confirmed.
"transmitted  from Singapore  Hab. Malayan peninsula, or adjoining islands (?)"; "Philippines, the type specimen having been received from Manila" (Lydekker, 1915:63).
"Les les Mariannes" (Mariana Isls, Guam); introduced.
Indonesia, Lesser Sunda Isls, "Timor" Isl.
"Inhabits the dry hilly forests of Ceylon, Borneo, Celebes and Java"; restricted to Ceylon (Sri Lanka; Lydekker, 1915:73).

Syntypes purchased in Shanghai market, but based on the place where Swinhoe saw the species in the wild, type locality restricted to China, Kiangsu, Chingkiang, Yangtze River, Deer Isl (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott, 1951:354).
USA, "On the plains and the highlands of the Missouri [River]".
"Habitat in thiopia et Sennar"; identified as Egypt, in captivity at Cairo (Thomas, 1911a:150); restricted to Sudan, Sennar, by Harper (1940:322).
Dem. Rep. Congo, "in sylvis fluvio Semliki adjacentibus" (= Semliki Forest, Mundala).
"Koossi-Thale", now identified as South Africa, Northern Cape Prov., Kuruman Dist., Khosis (Grubb, 1999).

No locality cited but the name is based on "Le bubale" of Buffon, "en Barbarie & dans toutes les parties septentrionales de l'Afrique", and on other sources. Restricted to Barbary by designation of the "Vache de Barbarie" of Perrault as the lectotype (Ruxton and Schwarz, 1929:575). Further restricted to Morocco (Lydekker, 1914a:5).
"Le cap de Bonne Esperance"; since restricted to syntype locality South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov., Steynsburg (Grubb, 1999).
No type locality indicated; since identified as Mozambique, Tette.
Kenya, "Africam orientalem, in ripis fl. Tana" (E bank of Tana River).

South Africa, "Die lander der Caffern, ziemlich tief ins land vom Cap gerechnet in grossen Waldern ohnmeit der Uchtermanns Brenjes hogde und Camdebo"; since selected as Eastern Cape Prov., Somerset East Dist., Agterbruintjieshoogte (Grubb, 1999).
Apparently "Kosi Fountain", but lectotype came from South Africa, North West Prov., Vryburg Dist., "Chue Spring, Maadji Mtn [Klein Heuningvlei]"; see Grubb (1999).
N Nigeria, "Bornou" (Borno Prov.).
South Africa, Northern Cape Prov., Kuruman Dist., "Makkwarin" (Matlhwareng) River.
No locality. Since restricted to South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Caledon, Swart River (Bigalke, 1948).

"Northern Somali-land"; according to the collector Clarke (in Sclater and Thomas, 1898:220), "about three hours from 'Bairwell' or about one day from 'Buroa Well, Habergerhagi's country'" (N Somalia, vicinity of Burao and Ber).
South Africa, "die Lander am Cap der guten Hoffnung", since restricted to " Cape Colony [Cape Prov.]" (Lydekker, 1914b:111).
"Habitat in India, Asia"; restricted by Zukowsky (1927:125) to "Trivandrum im sdlichsten Vorderindien nahe Kap Comorin" (India, Travancore, inland of Trivandrum).
Somalia, "in den Schluchten des Hekebo" (ravine in the Hekebo region); 35 mi (56 km) SW of Berbera (Moreau et al., 1946:437).
"Senegal".
"Hab. Doubtful. Type bought at Algiers"; "probably the interior of Algeria" (Lydekker, 1914b:66).
"the range of country from Kilimanjaro to Baringo and at various heights above 6000' [1829 m]"; restricted to "Kilimanjaro district" (Lydekker, 1914b:84) in Kenya (G. M. Allen, 1939:526).
Saudi Arabia, "Insel Farsan" (Farasan Isls).
India, "found on the rocky hills of Dukhun [the Deccan]".
Morocco, "Mogadore" (Mogador).
"Habitat in Africa"; restricted to Lower Egypt by Blaine (1913:292), west of the Nile River (Osborn and Helmy, 1980:508).
Yemen, Lahej.
No locality cited; based on "La Gazelle" of Buffon, from "Syri" (Syria).

"rapports du Sennaar [Sudan, Sennar] par M. Burton"; corrected to "desert between Giza and Wadi Natron, lower Egypt, as the type-specimen was brought to Paris by James Burton, circa 1833" (Flower, 1932:438).
Saudi Arabia, "Dhalm, about 150 miles [241 km] north-east of Mecca, central Arabia, 3500 feet [1067 m]".
"Somli-land" (= Somalia).

"Patria Antilopes subgutturosai Persia est. Inter mare caspicum & nigrum septentrionem versus usque ad pedem australem promontorii iugi alpini caucasici, vix ultra gradum latitudinis 42 procedit  per Georgiam  per Cardueliam et Cachetiam regis  Teflisi" (Georgia, steppes of E Transcaucasia, near Tbilisi).

"Mainland of Africa, north of the island of Zanzibar, about lat. 30S and long. 38E" and therefore apparently in Kenya, but shown to be correctly "Somalia, coast near Juba River" by Sclater and Thomas (1898) and Moreau et al. (1946) and more specifically, the vicinity of Chisimayo (Grubb, 2002).
Ethiopia, "Central Ogaden, 3000 feet [914 m]"; identified as "District immediately north of Imi and Karanle on the Webi Shebeli, Ogaden, Ethiopia, about 630'N, 4230'E" by Moreau et al. (1946:437).
Somalia,"near Brava, in the South Somali country".
E Somalia, "Gharabwein, within a day's march of Obbia [525'N, 4825'E], in the Mijertain country, Italian Somaliland".
"Abyssinie" (Ethiopia).
No locality cited; based on "Le Nanguer" of Buffon from "Sngal"; see discussion in Harper (1940).
Tanzania, "Western Kinyenye, in Ugogo".
"an dem stlichen Abhange Abyssiniens" (E Ethiopia); restricted by Lydekker (1914b:97) to "Tal E'Sabb, Abyssinia" (Ethiopia, El Shab Valley).
"Efulen, Bulu Country, Kamarun [Cameroon], 1500 ft. [457 m] above sea".

"in Chapani (Anglis French island) occisa insula prope Zanzibar in Lat. Austr. 69', Long. Orient. 3914' a Greenwich sita, fructibus dense tecta et fonte irrigata" (Tanzania, Chapani Isl, 3 km from Zanzibar).
"Habitat in Guinea, India"; restricted to "Guinea" (West Africa) by Thomas (1911a:152).
"Die Caffern"; now known to be South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape Dist., False Bay (Grubb, 1999).

"Bewohnt die Cafferen" (South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov., Kaffraria); since restricted to one of the syntypical localities: South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov., Somerset East Dist., Bruintjieshoogte (Grubb, 1999).
"Intra Siberiae limites maxime Dauuriam transmontanum, campos dico circa Ononem and Argunum, frequentat" (Russia, SE Transbaikalia, Chitinsk. Obl., upper Onon River).

"Habitat: the plains of Tibet, amid ravines and low bare hills", restricted to China, "Hundes district of Tibet" (Lydekker, 1914b:31) "but more likely the district north of Sikkim, where most of Hodgson's specimens were obtained after 1844" (Groves, 1967a:148).
China, "im sdlichen Ordos" (S Ordos desert); Groves (1967:149) stated that the type locality is the Chagrin Gol (or Steppe).

No locality cited; South Africa by implication; since restricted to Cape Colony (Lydekker, 1914a:148) or Cape of Good Hope (G. M. Allen, 1939:502); since selected as Western Cape Prov., Malmesbury Div., Swartland (Grubb, 1999:23).
No locality cited; South Africa by implication; Cape Colony (Lydekker, 1914a:157) or Cape of Good Hope (G. M. Allen, 1939:504); since selected as Western Cape Prov., Cape Peninsula (Grubb,1999:23).
Malawi, "Southern Angoniland".
Russia, Siberia, Yakutsia, River Wiljui or Vilyuy.
Russia, Siberia, Yakutsia, River Wiljui or Vilyuy.
"Habitat in summa Asia"; identified as W Kazakhstan, steppes along the Ural River.

"Habitat in Mexico, Florida"; identified as "Mexico" by Thomas (1911a:154); restricted to USA, C Kansas, "Quivera" by Hershkovitz (1957b); redesignated as USA, E New Mexico, Canadian River valley by McDonald (1981:62).
"Habitat in Africa, Asia"; restricted to "Bielowitza, Lithuania" (Poland, Bialowieza Forest) by Lydekker (1913:35).

Native "of the hills to the north-east and east of the Company's province of Chittagong in Bengal, inhabiting that range of hills which separate it from the country of Arracan" (Bangladesh, NE Chittagong).
"Habitat in Asia boreali"; "in regno Tibetano" according to Gmelin, in Linnaeus, 1788 (China, Tibetan Plateau); based on domesticated stock.
Indonesia, Java.
"Nord Cambodge" (Cambodia, near Tchep Village).

Linnaeus (1758) stated "Habitat in Poloniae depressis graminosis ferus Urus". "Urus" applies to the aurochs because Linnaeus' only source was Caesar in his "Gallic Wars" where the aurochs is described (Lydekker, 1912). Other authors have used the name "urus" for the European Bison Bison bonasus, in the 18th Century thought to be the wild form of domestic cattle. Thomas (1911a:154) proposed to restrict the type locality to Sweden, Upsala, applying taurus to domestic cattle.
No locality cited; restricted to "plains of Peninsular India" (Lydekker, 1914b:227).
"Habitat in Asia, cultus in Italia". Restricted by Thomas (1911a:154) to Italy, Rome, but Linnaeus' (1758) comment indicates Asia (India?).
Indonesia, "Island of Celebes" (Sulawesi).
Philippines, "l'ile de Mindoro".
Indonesia, Sulawesi, "des bois des hautes montagnes de la rgion centrale de Toradja".
"Vu Quang Nature Reserve, Vietnam 10525'E by 1815'N".
"Seecov Rivier" and "Akter Brunties hoogte", now restricted to South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov., Uitenhage district, Sunday River, Algoa Bay.
"Western Africa, Gambia".
Known to the Dutch "ad Promontorium B. Spei", restricted to South Africa, Western Cape Prov., near Cape Town by Shortridge (1934:607).
"native de l'Inde"; "plains of Peninsular India" (Lydekker, 1914b:222).
South Africa, KwaZulu-Natal, "Hills that border upon the northern shores of St. Lucia Bay, in the Zulu country, lat. 28 south".
Ethiopia, Bak Prov., "Arusi plateau of Gallaland, in the Sahatu Mountains, and south-east of Lake Zwei [Zwai], at an estimated height of 9000 feet [2,700 m] above sea level".
"Their origin is unknown, but I have reason to believe they [the syntypes] came from Western Africa".
"Abyssinia"; now known to be Ethiopia, Shoa Prov.
No locality cited but based on "Le Guib" of Buffon, from "Sngal".
Tanzania, Karagwe, E of Lake Victoria, at a lake named "Little Windermere" by Speke; identified as Bukoba district, Lake Lwelo, 2S, 3057'E by Moreau et al. (1946:441).
"Prom. B. Spei" (Cape of Good Hope); restricted to South Africa, south-eastern Cape Prov. [eastern part of Western Cape Prov.] by Grubb (1999:36).
"Africae borealori propria"; restricted to Algeria, Department of Oran (Harper, 1940).
India, Assam, "Mishmi mountains [Mishmi Hills]  in the Eastern Himalaya".
Russia, "in summis Caucasi jugis, circa fluviorum Terek et Kubam summas origines, itemque in Ossetino tractu et Cachetia" (Caucasus Mtns, between Malka and Baksan Rivers, east of Mt. Elbrus).
"Kaschmir"; restricted to Pakistan, Kashmir, Astor (Lydekker, 1913).
"Habitat in montosis"; identified as Sweden (Thomas, 1911a:152), based on domesticated stock.
"Habitat in Wallesiae praeruptis inaccessis"; identified as Switzerland, Valais by Thomas (1911a:152).

Egypt, "de la Haute-gypte  ou de Nubie"; Nubia (Lydekker, 1913:153; G. M. Allen, 1939:549) or Upper Egypt (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott, 1951:407), which are virtually synonymous; here restricted to Sudan, Northern Prov., Nubian Desert, east of Nile River.
"In den spanischen Pyrenen, auf den Gebirgen der Sierra de Randa und des Knigreiches Granada"; restricted to Spain, Pyrenees Mtns, Huesca, near Maladetta Pass (Harper, 1940).

"sylvas inter Udae et Birjussae fluviorum fontes ad ipsam calcem Sajensis"; "northern slope of Sayansk Mountains, in the neighbourhood of Munku Sardyx, west of Lake Baikal" (Lydekker, 1913:143) (Russia, Siberia, Sayan Mtns, near Munku-Sardyk).
"die hchsten felsigten Gebirge Abyssiniens  in den Provinzen Simen und Godjam"; restricted to Ethiopia, mountains of Simien (Lydekker, 1913:156).

"Les les du domaine du Japon"; "On ne la trouve que dans les parties de l'le de Nippon couvertes de hautes alpes, telle qu la partie, nomme Josino; puis sur les montagnes les plus leves de l'le de Sikok [Shikoku]"; restricted to "Nippon (Hondo) [Honshu], Japan" (Lydekker, 1913:200).
China, Sichuan, "Moupin" (Baoxing).
Burma, "Arakan Hills".
Indonesia, "Sumatra".
"Formosa [Taiwan], on the central ridge of the Snowy Mountains".
"the central region, equidistant from the snows on one hand, and the plains of India on the other;  between the Sutlege, west, and the Teesta, east,  in Nepal proper" (Nepal, Himalayas).
India, "Neilgherry Hills" (Nilgiri Hills).
Oman, "Jebel Taw, Jebel Akhdar Range".
Nepal, "the district of Jemlah, between the sources of the Sargew and Sampoo" (Jemla Hills).
China, Tibet, "Dre on banks of Yigrong Tso (Lake) in Po Me [Bomi]. 9,000 ft [2743 m]".
Russia, "Sibrie" (Amurland, Bureja Mtns).
"a native of the Himalayah range and the mountains of the Nepaul frontier" (Nepal, Himalayas).
"du nord de la Chine"; China, Sichuan, Moupin (Baoxing).

"d'Amerique"; restricted to the type locality of Ovis montanus Ord, 1815, the Columbia River area, where observed by Lewis and Clark, in "the Cascade Mountains, and the nearby range" (Hollister, 1912:185) "near Mt Adams, Washington" (Dalquest, 1948:409) (USA, Washington, Cascade Mountains, Mt. Adams).

Canada, Manitoba, "Bewohnt anjezt hauptsachlich Neuwallis an der Hudsonsbay ban zwischen Seefalber- (Seals) und Churchill-Fluss zwischen dem 59 bis 61. Grad Breite" (between Seal and Churchill Rivers).
"Habitat in Siberia"; since identified as Kazakhstan, Vostochno-Kazakhstansk. Obl., Altai Mtns, Bukhtarma; near Ust-Kamenogorsk.
"Habitat in siccis apricis calidis"; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:153); domesticated stock.
"the interior parts of Canada"; identified as Canada, Alberta, Mountains on Bow River, near Exshaw (Anderson, 1947:184).

USA, Alaska, "killed by the Indians on some mountains south of Fort Yukon, and on the west bank of the river"; interpreted as "Mountains west of Fort Reliance, Alaska, on divide between Tanana and Yukon Rivers" (Miller, 1924:497), or "Mountains south of Fort Yukon on west bank of Yukon River, Alaska; probably Tanana Hills" (Miller and Kellog, 1955:823).
"den Bergen der Halbinsel Kamtschatka" (Russia, E Kamchatka).
China, Tibet, Kooti Pass in Arrun Valley, Tingri Maiden.
"The Himlaya"; restricted to "the Tibetan frontier of Nepal" (Lydekker, 1913:127).
China, "Obere Jangtse-Talschlucht bei Batang" (upper Yangtze Gorge, Drupalong, south of Batang).
Spain, "Mont. Pyren." (Pyrenees).
"Habitat in alpibus Helveticis summis inaccessis" (Switzerland).
Tanzania, "Zanzibar".
"Africa occidentalis (Gabun)" (Gabon, Gabon River).
"Sierra Leone".
"Liberia"; since identified as Junk River opposite Schieffelinsville, Sharp-Hill (Khn, 1965).
"West Africa, Gaboon" (Gabon).
South Africa, KwaZulu-Natal, "Port Natal" (Durban).
"Guinea" but apparently Ghana, Shama (see comments).
"Gaboon" (Gabon).
Equatorial Guinea, "Fernando Po" (= Bioko).
"Sierra Leone, Village of Waterloo".
"Habitat in montibus Sierrae Leone & regionibus susuensium fluvios Pongas & Quia adjacentibus frequens"; since restricted to Sierra Leone, vicinity of Freetown (Grubb et al., 1998).
"High altitudes on Mt. Kilima-njaro, frequenting the highest points" (Tanzania, Mt. Kilimanjaro; at 2400 m according to Grimshaw et al., 1995).
"district des Stanley-Falls" (Dem. Rep. Congo, near Stanley Falls).
"Sierra Leone".
"Sierra Leone".
South Africa, "Lange Kloof"; since identified as borders of Western and Eastern Cape, Uniondale and Humansdorp Dist., Langkloof, 3348'S, 23<sup> </sup>to 24<sup> </sup>30'E; see Grubb (1999:21).
"Habitat in Africa"; based on a specimen seen by Grimm in the fort at Cape Town (Thomas, 1911a:153) so now known to be South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape Town.
No locality given. Here selected as the Tunisian Sahara.
"Inconnue"; now thought to be South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Plettenberg Bay (Grubb, 1999).
"Promontoriae bonae Spei missas"; since restricted to South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Swellendam Dist.

"The great mountain range in the county of Mataveld", and "On the northern side of the Cashan range of mountiains, about a degree and a half south of the tropic of Capricorn", since specified as South Africa, North West Prov., Krugersdorp and Rustenburg, Magaliesberg (Grubb, 1999).
Eritrea, "in den Niederungen der Kstenlandschaft bei Massaua" (Red Sea coast west of Massawa).
Sudan, Northern Kordofan Prov., "bewohnen die grossen Steppen von Haraza [vicinity of Jebel Haraza]".
"India"; understood to be South Africa (Thomas, 1911a:152).
"Arabiae et forte Lybiae proprium animal"; restricted to Arabia (Lydekker, 1914b:130).

"about twenty-five days' journey north of the Orange River between Latakoo and the western coast of Africa". Since restricted to Botswana, Gaborone, the top reaches of the Notwani River; see Smithers (1971:233) and Grubb (1999:25-26).
"Senegal".
"Banks of the river Zoaga, lat. 21"; since identified as Botswana, Botletle River, near Lake Ngami (Smithers, 1971:233).

Sudan, Upper Nile Prov., "Bahr el abiad" or according to the collector, von Heuglin (Nov. Act. Acad. Caes. Leop. Carol. Germ. Nat. Curios., Abhand. 30, part 2, p. 14 [1863]), "am Sobat, Bhar ghasl und untern Kir" (Bahr el Abiad or White Nile, Bahr el Ghazal, Kir River or lower Bahr el Jebel, and Sobat River); restricted to "Mouth of the Bahr el Ghazal at its junction with the White Nile" (Roosevelt and Heller, 1914:519).
"Thirty or forty miles above Libonta"; since identified as Zambia, Barotseland, Chobe Valley, near Libonda at 400'S, 2315'E.
"Ouwe-hoeck", now specified as South Africa, Western Cape, Caledon, Houhoek Pass; see Skead (1973:79).
"Habitat ad Cap. Bn. Sp." (Cape of Good Hope); since selected as South Africa, Free State, Bethulie, based on known collecting localities of syntypes (Grubb, 1999:25).
No type locality originally identified; restricted to eastern Cape Colony (Lydekker, 1914a:221) (South Africa, Eastern Cape).
No locality cited; based on "Le Nagor" of Buffon from Senegal, "dans les terres voisines de l'le de Gore" (mainland opposite Gori Isl).
"Habitat in Oceano Groenlandico" (= Greenland Sea).
Algoa Bay, Cape of Good Hope, South Africa.
None given, listed as Norway, Finnmark, Nord Kapp (vicinity of North Cape) by Eschricht and Reinhardt (1861).
Japan.
France, "pris aux environs de la rade de Cherbourg", Mancha.
Near Belgrano, Prov. Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Germany, Schleswig-Holstein, Lubeck Bay, near Gromitz (see Rudolphi, 1822).
Burma, "found its way into the Thaybyoo Choung, which runs into the Gulf of Martaban between the Sittang and Beeling Rivers, and about equidistant from each".
UK, Scotland, Firth of Forth ("Habitat in Mari Scotico").
"Habitat in Oceano Europeao", restricted to Norway, near Svalbard, Spitsbergen Sea by Thomas (1911a).
USA, "de la nouvelle Angleterre" (= coast of New England).
Sweden, "p Grsn i Roslagen"; "Benen lgo 840 fot frn hafsstranden, ungefr 12  15 fot fver hafvets yta" (= Uppland, Graso Isl).
"Inhab. W. Australia" (= southern hemisphere, temperate waters; see Baker, 1985).
Chile, "de la terre de Feu et dans le dtroit de Magellan" (= Tierra del Fuego, Straits of Magellan).
None given, listed as Pacific Ocean, off the coast of Chile by Gray (1850:112).
South Africa, Western Cape Prov., "Inhab. Cape of Good Hope".
"captur sur la cte nord-est de la Nouvelle-Zlande." (= New Zealand, north coast).
Cape of Good Hope.
E North Atlantic ("Oceano Europaeo").
"South Seas."
"South Seas".
UK, Scotland, "in Scapay Bay, in Pomona, one of the Orkneys".
France, Finistere, "envoy de Brest".
"Collected at the mouth of Lutong River, Baram, Borneo."
None given, listed as North Sea, Faeroe Isls (Denmark) (uncertain) by Gray (1846:36).
None given in original description, given by Gray (1846:35) as UK, England, "North Sea, coast of Norfolk.", and by Gray (1850) as Great Yarmouth.
"South Atlantic Ocean, off the coast of Patagonia", Argentina, 1 days sail north of the Straits of LeMaire.
Pacific Ocean, "entre la Nouvelle-Hollande et le cap Horn [= between Australia and Cape Horn]...par 49 [S] de latitude".
USA, "obtained at San Francisco, California".
South Africa, Western Cape Prov., "Inhab. Cape of Good Hope".
"North Pacific Ocean, latitude 46 6' 50" N., 134 5' W. from Greenwich.", 10W of Astoria, Oregon, USA.
Indian Ocean, "dans les environs du cap sud de la terre de Dimen, et par consquent vers le quarante-quatrime degr de latitude australe." (= about 44S, 141E, south of Tasmania).
"Inhab. East coast of India, the harbour of Vizagapatam" (= Vishakhapatnam Harbor, in Bay of Bengal).
E North Atlantic ("Oceano Europaeo").
None given, unknown.
UK, England, "in the great fen of Lincolnshire beneath the turf, in the neighborhood of the ancient town of Stamford". (subfossil).
Peru, Loreto, Rio Maranon above Pebas.
China, Guangdong Prov., Zhujiang Kou (mouth of Canton River).
"aus Kamerun" (= Cameroon), Cameroun Oriental, Bay of Warships, near Douala.
None given, unknown (possibly India, see Gray, 1843).
None given, unknown.
"an der stlichen Kste von Sdamerika; wir karpunirten ihn in der Gegend des Rio de la Plata." (= South Atlantic Ocean near Rio de la Plata, off coast of Argentina and Uruguay).
"dcouvert un aux les du Cap-Vert". (= off Cape Verde Isls, West Africa).
None given, unknown.
Coast of France.

"Habitat in Oceano Septentrionali Americae, Europae." (= northern seas of Europe and America).
South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape of Good Hope (" dcouvert au Cap,"). Almost certainly erroneous; unknown today from coast of Africa.
Argentina, Buenos Aires, "capturado en Punta Colares, cerca de Quilmes".
"Habitat in Oceano Europaeo, & Balthico." (= Baltic Sea, "Swedish Seas").
"from the northeast shore of Punta San Felipe, Baja California Norte, Gulf of California, Mexico".
Argentina, Buenos Aires, "captured in the mouth of the River Plata".
USA, Alaska, "in the strait west of Adakh [sic] Island, one of the Aleutian group".
South Africa, Western Cape Prov., "rapporte des mers du cap de Bonne-Esprance" (= Cape of Good Hope).
India, Andhra Pradesh (= Madras Presidency), "taken at Waltair".
"Habitat in Oceano Septentrionali.", restricted to Netherlands, Middenpiat by Husson and Holthuis (1974).
India, West Bengal, "in the Ganges. . . rivers, and creeks, which intersect in the delta of that river to the South, S. E. and east of Calcutta." (= Hooghly River, Ganges River delta).
Pakistan, "from the Indus" River.
"sur la cte du Brsil.", probably upper Amazon River.
"Tung Ting Lake, about 600 miles up the Yangtze River, [Hunan] China".
Uruguay, "qui a t pris  Montevideo" = mouth of the Rio de La Plata near Montevideo.
"chou sur la cte, dans le port d'Akaroa, presqu'le de Bancks, dans la Nouvelle-Zlande." (= New Zealand, Canterbury Prov., Akaroa).
Russia, Commander Isls, "found stranded in Stare Gavan, on the eastern shore of Bering Island".

"See Mr. Pennant's [1769] British Zoology Vol. 3, p. 43, where it is called the beaked whale, and very well described;" Pennant (1769:43) gave Maldon (England) as the locality and 1717 as the date stranded.
"found upon the sea-beach of Lewis Island in the Dampier Archipelago, north-western Australia."
Australia, Queensland, "found at Mackay".

Russia, Commander Isls, "Bering Island".
Chatham Isl, New Zealand.

France, "dans le dpartement des Bouches-du-Rhne, entre de Fos et l'embouchure du Galgeon" (= between Fos and the mouth of the Galgeon River).
